III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/12/25, a youth was arguing with a staff member. The staff
member snatched a pencil from the youth who was doing
encouraged journaling. The staff member instigated the youth to
"do something." The house manager told the youth to go away
from the staff member. The staff member grabbed the youth by
the arms and wrists and again told her to "do something."
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via telephone on 6/19/2025.
However, there was no answer.
Chief Administrator (CA) and President were interviewed on
6/18/25 face to face at Safehaus with MDHHS worker. CA was
not present to witness the incident, but the incident was reported
to him. CA reported the incident began with Youth A being
accused of hiding a knife in her bedroom. CA reported Safehaus
has a no touch, no restraint policy. No video or camera footage
was available in or outside of the home.
President reported Youth A was accused of hiding a knife at
Safehaus Too so she provided approval to complete a bed/check.
President reported Youth A’s bedroom and the kitchen were
checked but there were no knives missing or found. President
reported youth can only have markers and pencils out at a certain
time and that’s to journal. After that, youth are to put the markers
and pencils away. President reported Youth A was using the
markers to draw on herself and reported this being a coping
mechanism Youth A was told to use instead of self-harming, but
Youth A wasn’t allowed to use markers/pencil if it wasn’t approved
arts and craft time. President reported Staff 1 took the markers
and pencils away from Youth A, because Youth A refused to put
them away when initially asked. President reported Staff 1
admitted to grabbing Youth A by the wrist. President reported Staff
1 being pregnant and fearful that Youth A would harm her by
stabbing her in the belly so she grabbed Youth A’s wrist.
2

Safety planning was discussed. President and CA plan to meet
with Staff 1 and will ensure Staff 1 completes refresher course on
appropriate Behavior Management. Staff 1 is on a restricted work
schedule. Youth A is no longer at the facility and has returned
home.
Youth A was interviewed on 6/20/25 face to face with MDHHS
worker. DCWL consultant was present by phone. Youth A
reported journaling in her therapy notebook when Staff 1 told her
to put the pencil away, but she refused to do so. Youth A reported
Youth B was also sitting at the table completing therapy
homework. Youth A reported Staff 1 snatched the pencil out of her
hand and snatched a marker out of Youth B’s hand. Youth A
reported Staff 1 accused them of using the pencil inappropriately.
Youth A reported having marks on her arm from using the
markers. Youth A reported Staff 1 told both youth if they were not
going to follow the rules, they did not need pencils or markers.
Youth A reported Staff 2 came over to the house to check on
Youth A and Staff 1. Youth A reported Staff 2 asked Youth A to
separate from Staff 1 and to go into a separate room. Youth A
reported the only way to leave the room and go with Staff 2 was to
pass by Staff 1. Youth A reported as she was walking passed
Staff 1, Staff 1 grabbed Youth A by the wrist as Youth A tried to
leave. Youth A reported having no marks or bruises on her wrist
but reported it being sore after the incident.
Youth B mother was interviewed via telephone on 7/28/25.
Youth B mother did not report any concerns for her daughter’s
wellbeing while at Safehaus. It was reported Youth B did not
mention an incident involving markers or any other youth being
physically touched at Safehaus.
A telephone call was made to interview Youth D and Youth
D’s father on 7/21/2025. However, per Youth D’s father, Youth D
was away at camp until Friday, July 25th. Youth D’s father
reported having many concerns with Safehaus, because his
daughter reported staff are mean at the facility. However, Youth
D’s father went on to say Youth D has been known to tell lies so
he is uncertain what to believe. A call was made on 7/25/25 to
interview Youth D. However, it was reported Youth D was not
available and that Youth D had permission to call once back in the
house. A return call was not received.
Youth E was interviewed face to face on 6/28/25 with MDHHS
worker.
3

Youth E reported being at Safehaus a couple days and does not
know Youth A. Youth E reported not being familiar with most staff
but felt safe at the facility. Youth E reported no concerns with how
staff communicate to youth. Youth E reported she has not seen
Staff get physical with other youth during interventions or
redirection. Youth A reported markers/pencils can only be used
during arts and craft and are otherwise locked up.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 6/25/25 face to face at Safehaus
with MDHHS worker. Staff 1 reported after breakfast, a youth told
her Youth A was hiding forks in the house. Staff 1 reported after
completing a bed/house check, there were no forks found. Staff 1
reported the time to have the markers and pencil was up and she
was collecting markers/pencils. Staff 1 reported youth are only
able to use markers for one hour a day. Staff 1 reported Youth A
got upset, because she did not want to stop journaling. Staff 1
reported Youth A started to threaten her by saying “Bitch I’ll fuck
you up”. Staff 1 reported Youth A walked past her, so Staff 1
grabbed both Youth A wrists. Staff 1 reported being pregnant and
fearful that Youth A would hit her stomach. Staff 1 reported only
grabbing Youth A wrist for a few seconds and releasing. Staff 1
reported walking to the next room to calm down and Staff 2
assisted with calming Youth A down. Staff 1 reported having an
understanding that what she did was inappropriate, but she
wanted to protect herself. Staff 1 denied there being any marks or
bruises on Youth A after the incident. Staff 1 reported there were
no knives found around the house, but a lot of markers which
Youth are not allowed to have. Staff 1 reported markers were
found under youths pillows, some were hidden in the couch and in
the drawers. Staff 1 reported Youth are able to use markers as an
alternative methods to cope with their emotions and for drawing
but parents do not agree with this due to ink stains. Staff 1
reported she did not grab any markers or pencils out of Youth A
hands. Staff 1 reported Youth A eventually gave her the pencils
after asking Youth A several times. Staff 1 reported being on
probation with a restricted scheduled and cannot supervise youth
alone. Staff 1 admitted to not being familiar with how to
appropriately de-escalate a youth and felt like she could use
additional training.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 7/30/25. Staff 2
reported being called over to Safehaus Too to assist Staff 4. Staff
2 reported not hearing Staff 1 say anything to Youth A initially but
reported seeing Youth A upset and escalating so she made efforts
to separate Youth A from Staff 1. Staff 2 reported making efforts to
separate Youth A from Staff 1 by asking Youth A to leave the
4

area. Staff 2 reported the only way for Youth A to get to Staff 2
was to walk past Staff 1. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 immediately got
up out of her chair and jumped at Youth A telling her to “do
something”. Staff 2 reported Youth A looked back at Staff 1 and
then Staff 1 grabbed Youth A’s hand. Staff 2 reported trying to
redirect Staff 1 by telling her about the rules and how It was
against policy to grab youth. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 responded
back saying “I don’t fuck with kids” and “I will fuck one of these
kids up”. Staff 2 reported also telling Staff 1 not to use derogatory
language.
Staff 3 was contacted on 7/7/2025 and 7/28/25 but was
unsuccessful due to the telephone being disconnected.
Supervisor was contacted via telephone on 6/25/25, 7/7/2025,
7/28/25, but was unsuccessful.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face on 6/28/25 with MDHHS
worker. Staff 5 reported she was not present on the day of the
incident but is familiar with Youth A and reported she has never
seen Youth A with behavioral issues. Staff 5 also reported Youth
A has never been observed getting aggressive with staff
members. Staff 5 reported she has never worked with Staff 1.
A Pre-Disposition Meeting was held with MDHHS worker on
7/21/2025. There were no findings.
Documentation:
Youth C and Youth C’s mother were interviewed by MDHHS
worker on 7/16/2025. DCWL consultant was not present for
this interview. Per MDHHS worker, A call was placed to the
mother of Youth C. Youth C reported Safehaus staff were being
mean and rude towards her. Regarding the incident, Youth C
reported Staff 1 was yelling at Youth A for no apparent reason.
Youth C reported Youth A was writing in her notebook when Staff
1 suddenly snatched the marker from her hand. According to
Youth C, Staff 1 appeared upset and said that the youth were
drawing on themselves and not using the markers appropriately.
Youth C reported Staff 1 began yelling at Youth A, claiming that
using markers to write on oneself is a form of self-harm and is not
appropriate. Youth C added they have been told in therapy to use
markers as a coping strategy instead of self-harming, but this was
not permitted at the facility. Youth C also reported Staff 1
threatened Youth A, saying she was going to "beat this child's
ass." Youth C reported Staff 2 came to assist and asked Youth A
to speak with her. As Youth A walked past Staff 1 to reach Staff 2,
5

Staff 1 grabbed Youth A’s arms aggressively. Youth C denied
knowing whether Staff 1 was pregnant and stated that Youth A
never threatened Staff 1 at any point. Youth C affirmed that this
was the only incident that occurred between Staff 1 and Youth A.
Staff 1’s personnel file: Staff 1 received discipline on 3/14/25
and 5/6/25 for incidents unrelated to this investigation. Staff 1
completed introduction to motivational interviewing on 5/6/2025
and 5/8/2025. Staff also completed CPI training on 2/22/24.
Incident Report received on 6/24/25, dated 6/12/25 and
authored by Staff 1 indicates Staff 1 collected markers from
Youth A due to Youth A drawing all over her body. Youth A
threatened to harm Staff 1, so Staff 1 contacted Staff 2 for
assistance. Staff 2 came over and asked what was going on.
Youth A exploded saying how upset she was and Youth A
repeatedly threatened staff. Youth A walked past Staff 1, Staff 1
was afraid client was going to hit her so Staff 1 grabbed Youth A
arms to prevent any harm coming their way considering staff was
pregnant. Youth A became upset that staff touched her arm.
Youth A then walked over to another room (living room) with Staff
2.
Written Statements received on 7/18/25 dated 6/13/2025 and
authored by Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D. These
reports are consistent with Youth A and Staff 1 interviews.
Recipient Rights Complaint Report received on 7/18/2025
dated 6/12/2025 authored by Youth A. Unfortunately, this is
handwritten and is not legible. This document also includes Youth
B, Youth C, and Youth D written grievances.
Hands Off Policy: Indicates that any form of physical restraint not
be utilized to restrict and secure the movements of the residents in
care. It is the philosophy of Safehaus that staff take the “Hands
Off” appropriate when intervening with residents. Staff will utilize
approved and trained verbal de-escalation techniques for
residents in crisis.
Procedure:
1. All staff must adhere to the Hands-Off technique
2. All Staff is to be trained in approved de-escalation
techniques at the time of hiring and on a quarterly basis.
3. All Emergency Physical Interventions must be reported
immediately to the Supervisor on Duty, President of
Safehaus, or CEO.
6

4. All Emergency Physical intervention are to be documented
through the Safehaus Incident Report System.
5. All emergency physical interventions will be reported to the
State Licensing Consultant by the Chief Administrator
within 24 hours.
6. Residents who are involved in any Emergency Physical
Intervention must be checked by a nurse or designee for
injuries.
7. The Supervisor on Duty will notify the referring agency of
the emergency physical intervention.
8. Failure to follow the “Hands Off” policy may lead to
suspension or termination of employment from Safehaus.
9. This policy will be reviewed at the time of hire and signed
by the employee.
10. Only non-violent crisis intervention techniques (CPI) are to
be utilized if the resident is harming another resident of
staff and they are in imminent danger.
Crisis Procedure:
1. If a staff member identifies a situation that can be
potentially volatile, support staff is to notify the Supervisor
on Duty and Clinical Director.
2. Law Enforcement is to be contacted if Staff feels the
incident is becoming too dangerous. Support staff is to
remove children away from the volatile area.
3. If a resident attempts to exit the building, Do not try to stop
them. Let the resident exit if necessary and contact Law
Enforcement, Clinical Director, and Supervisor on Duty.
4. The Clinical Director will determine if the child needs to be
screened for a higher level of care.
Decorum/Rules for Conduct for Staff Policy: It is the policy of
Safehaus to provide written decorum/rules of conduct to guide
staff conduct and discipline.
1. “No Tolerance Policy”: The Safehaus will not tolerate
mistreatment of residents. Verbal abuse, swearing,
cursing, threatening, improper or unnecessary physical
restraint of residents is cause for immediate termination of
employment.
2. Treat all residents with respect and dignity. Mistreatment of
residents verbally or physically will not be tolerated.
3. Use acceptable language at all times. Do not curse at
residents or staff members. Gestures, mimicking, belittling,
and name calling are never to occur.
4. Do not criticize other staff in the presence of residents.
7

5. Dress appropriately. You are especially to follow the rules
of dress appearance required for the residents and staff.
6. It is important that staff members support each other at all
times.
7. Disagreements between staff members MUST NEVER be
held where a resident may see or hear them.
8. Be in control of your emotions.
9. Do not try to influence the residents with personal religious
or political philosophies.
10. Do not accept gratuities from residents or their families.
GROUP A:
The following violations are considered cause for immediate
termination
1. Striking or threatening or attempting to strike a resident,
child, visitor, staff member, or supervisor.
2. Any physical management.
3. Swearing, cursing, calling a resident names, threatening a
resident, or cursing in the presence of children.
Analysis The agency was found to be in non-compliance based on
interviews with staff and youth. Safehaus has a Hands-Off Policy
that prohibits staff from physically touching youth unless the youth
poses an imminent risk to themselves or others. According to Staff
2, Youth A was able to de-escalate once she intervened. Staff 1,
who reported being pregnant, admitted to grabbing Youth A by
both wrists out of fear that Youth A might harm her stomach. Both
Youth A and Staff 2 confirmed that Staff 1 grabbed Youth A by the
wrists during the incident.
Technical Assistance:
Staff Member 1 completed Crisis Prevention Intervention (CPI)
training on February 22, 2024. As of the date of this report, the
staff member is overdue for the annual refresher training. In
accordance with regulatory best practices and agency policy, CPI
training must be completed on an annual basis to ensure staff
remain proficient in current de-escalation techniques and behavior
intervention strategies. Timely completion of refresher training is
critical to maintaining a safe and supportive environment for both
staff and individuals receiving services.
It is recommended the agency implement a tracking system or
reminder protocol to ensure all staff are re-certified within the
required timeframe to remain in compliance with state licensing
standards and to uphold the safety and quality of care.
8

Conclusion Violation Established

Type

Investigation Interviews:
Staff 1 was interviewed on 6/25/25 face to face at Safehaus

did not want to stop journaling. Staff 1 reported Youth A started to
threaten her by saying “Bitch I’ll fuck you up”
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 7/30/25.
Staff 2 did not hear Staff 1 initially say anything to Youth A but
observed Youth A becoming upset and attempted to de-escalate
by asking her to leave the area. Staff 1 then got up, confronted

Staff 2 reminded her that physical contact was against policy, Staff
1 responded, “I don’t fuck with kids” and “I will fuck one of these
kids up.”
Youth C and Youth C mother was interviewed by MDHHS
worker on 7/16/2025. DCWL consultant was not present for
this interview. Per MDHHS worker, Youth C reported being
present when the incident took place. Youth C reported Staff 1
threatened Youth A, saying she would “beat this child’s ass.”

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131
Section Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
Description required.
(1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation A staff member was told to withhold reporting an incident that
occurred on 6/12/25 between another staff member and a youth.
10

The youth was grabbed by the arm during the incident. The
incident wasn't reported by staff until 6/18/25.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 7/30/25.
Staff 2 reported being present when the incident occurred
between Youth A and Staff 1. Staff 2 reported there being other
youth home, including Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D who also
witnessed the incident. Staff 2 reported being called by President
to assist with Youth A and Staff 1. Staff 2 reported writing an
incident report immediately but was told by President not to file the
report until Monday, July 14th although the rule is filing
immediately after an incident has occurred. Staff 2 reported
challenging President on the decision to report the incident to
Centralized Intake. Staff 2 reported Staff 4 was present the next
day following the incident and was also told not to report the
incident until Monday, July 14th. Staff 2 reported being told to wait
to report the incident on Monday because Youth A would no
longer be in the program. Staff 2 reported President made this
decision to avoid an investigation from DCWL. Staff 2 reported
Youth A was triggered by Staff 1 taking the markers. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 as being the aggressor, because she reported
Youth A was calm by the time she walked past Staff 1 to get to
Staff 2. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 being inappropriate with Youth A
and in need of training of how to effectively communicate with
youth. Staff 2 reported statements were requested to be
completed by all staff and youth and were provided to President.
She advised that there were no concerns with Youth A hiding
forks or knives in the home. Staff 2 reported being terminated from
employment right after making the incident report. Staff 2 reported
having over 20 years of experience working with youth and was
hired to improve the program. Staff 2 reported once she tried to
implement change, there was always push back. Staff 2 reported
being told she was overqualified for the position. However, Staff 2
reported she believed she was let go after she decided to do what
was right and report the incident. Staff 2 reported being terminated
on 6/13/2025.
Chief Administrator and President participated in exit
conference on 7/28/25 with MDHHS.
An exit conference was completed. The concerns regarding staff
being told not to contact Central Intake and concerns with youth
not being allowed to have markers as a therapeutic option were
discussed. CA and President denied telling Staff 1 and Supervisor
not to call in a CPS complaint.
11

CA reported Staff 1 was terminated from Safehaus due to being
overqualified.
Staff 4 was interviewed in person on 8/14/2025 at Safehaus.
Staff 4 reported being a Supervisor employed at Safehaus and
worked on 6/13/25, the day after the incident involving Staff 1 and
Youth A occurred. Staff 4 reported upon her arrival, she was
informed about the incident and told by Staff 2 the incident reports
and resident complaints had already been completed. However,
she reported the President requested she complete a new incident
report and re-collect the resident complaints. Staff 4 recalled being
confused by this request, as Staff 2 had already completed these
tasks. Staff 4 asked the President whether a report had been
called into Centralized Intake, and whether the incident reports
had been submitted to the recipients' rights case manager. Staff 4
reported the President instructed her not to call Centralized Intake
on 6/13/25 and to instead leave the incident reports in the case
manager’s mailbox, who would call in the complaint on Monday,
6/14/25. Staff 4 reported talking to case manager a few days later
who did not recall receiving the documents in her mailbox. Staff 4
acknowledged that she was aware of the child abuse reporting
protocol and understood that abuse or neglect should be reported
immediately, but she did not challenge the President’s decision.
She further reported Staff 3 ultimately called the incident into
Centralized Intake, contrary to the President’s instructions to wait.
Staff 4 reported being uncertain about what transpired between
the President and Staff 3 but was aware that Staff 3 was
immediately terminated after challenging President decision.
Documents:
Adverse Incident Procedures Policy: It is the responsibility of
all staff to REPORT ADVERSE INCIDENTS (such as truancy,
attempted suicide, sexual contact, accidents, injuries, misconduct
of staff, etc.) according to the following procedures:
1. Notify the Supervisor on Duty IMMEDIATELY. Submit a
follow-up description of the incident in writing on an
Adverse Incident Report form using format outlined in #6
below.
2. The staff is also to note the Adverse Incident in the Team
Debriefing Log. The Supervisor on Duty will review the
debriefing logs when making rounds to ensure reporting of
all incidents.
3. The Supervisor on Duty is to notify the resident’s therapist
IMMEDIATELY if a serious incident has occurred.
4. When the therapist is not on duty and the incident is of a
SERIOUS nature, the therapist is to be telephoned by the
12

Supervisor on Duty for directions on management of the
residents in the incident. The Supervisor and the Clinical
Director should be telephoned for emergency consultation
when the therapist cannot be reached.
5. The Supervisor on Duty will give the staff directions on
management of the incident until the therapist can be
contacted.
6. The Supervisor on Duty is to contact administrative staff,
the therapist, and the Clinical Director whenever there is a
serious incident. Administrative staff will ensure that an
investigation is initiated.
7. All adverse incidents shall be reported in writing to the
Supervisor on Duty. The original form is to be sent to the
Chief Administrator and President of Safehaus. Copies of
the form are to be sent to the resident’s therapist, the
Supervisor’s office, nurse, Director of Clinical Services, and
the Treatment Team log. The report shall include the
following:
A. Date of incident.
B. Time of incident.
C. Staff involved.
D. Resident(s) involved.
E. Summary of incident.
F. Procedure followed to manage incident.
G. Signature of person submitting report.
8. The Supervisor on Duty will review the Adverse Incident
Report and add recommendations and actions to take to
resolve the incident. The Supervisor will distribute the
Adverse Incident Report as indicated above (#6).
9. The Adverse Incident Report reviewer will then determine if
the incident reported is cause for investigation or a Sentinel
Event Root Cause Analysis.
10. See categories of Adverse Incidents.
11. If a resident is involved in a physical intervention, the
Supervisor on Duty must ensure that the resident is seen
by the nurse for a head-to-toes check. The findings are to
be documented on a Medical Screening Form.
12. The Health Services staff will complete the Medical
Screening Form whenever there is an injury to the resident
and whenever there is a physical intervention or seclusion.
The Medical Screening Form will be distributed by the
Health Services staff and the original Medical Screening
Form is to be placed in the resident’s medical chart.
13. Health Services staff may attach photographs of the injury
to the original Medical Screening Form.
13

Adverse Incident Procedures: In the event of an adverse
incident, staff must immediately notify the Supervisor on Duty and
submit a written report using the designated format. The incident
must also be documented in the Team Debriefing Log. If the
incident is serious, the Supervisor must inform the resident’s
therapist right away, and if the therapist is unavailable, contact the
Clinical Director for further guidance. The Supervisor provides
interim management instructions and ensures all relevant parties,
including administrative staff, are informed to initiate an
investigation. A detailed Adverse Incident Report must be
completed, reviewed, and distributed to designated personnel. If
physical intervention occurs, a nurse must conduct a medical
check, and any injuries are to be documented using a Medical
Screening Form, with possible photo evidence, and placed in the
resident’s medical chart.
Reporting Abuse and Neglect Policy: Safehaus policy requires
that all incidents and suspected incidents of consumer abuse or
neglect be reported immediately to on-call staff or a supervisor
and formally documented in writing within 24 hours. These
completed reports must then be submitted within the same 24-
hour period to appropriate regulatory and law enforcement
agencies, including law enforcement, Protective Services (adult or
child), the Adult Foster Care (AFC) consultant if applicable, and
the Community Mental Health (CMH) Recipient Rights Director for
CMH consumers. The agency also requires that completed
reports be provided to the affiliate Recipient Rights Office and the
Executive Director. Staff are protected by the Whistleblowers Act
when reporting abuse or neglect. Additional reporting procedures
must comply with applicable laws and regulatory requirements.
Incident Report is dated 6/12/2025 and the date of the actual
